Background.value: Discovered in 1493 by Christopher COLUMBUS who named it for his brother Bartolomeo, Saint Barthelemy was first settled by the French in 1648. In 1784, the French sold the island to Sweden, which renamed the largest town Gustavia, after the Swedish King GUSTAV III, and made it a free port; the island prospered as a trade and supply center during the colonial wars of the 18th century. France repurchased the island in 1877 and took control the following year. It was placed under the administration of Guadeloupe. Saint Barthelemy retained its free port status along with various Swedish appellations such as Swedish street and town names, and the three-crown symbol on the coat of arms. In 2003 the islanders voted to secede from Guadeloupe, and in 2007 the island became a French overseas collectivity.

Environment - current issues.value: with no natural rivers or streams, fresh water is in short supply, especially in summer, and provided by desalinization of sea water, collection of rain water, or imported via water tanker

Location.value: Caribbean, island between the Caribbean Sea and the North Atlantic Ocean; located in the Leeward Islands (northern) group; Saint Barthelemy lies east of the US Virgin Islands

Natural resources.value: few natural resources; beaches foster tourism

Terrain.value: hilly, almost completely surrounded by shallow-water reefs, with plentiful beaches

Area - comparative.value: less than one-eighth the size of Washington, DC

Climate.value: tropical, with practically no variation in temperature; has two seasons (dry and humid)

Ethnic groups.value: white, Creole (mulatto), black, Guadeloupe Mestizo (French-East Asia)

Country name.abbreviation: Saint-Barth (French); St. Barts or St. Barths (English)

Legislative branch.description: unicameral Territorial Council (19 seats; members elected by absolute majority vote in the first round vote and proportional representation vote in the second round; members serve 5-year terms)

Legislative branch.elections: last held on 18 March 2012 (next to be held in July 2017)
Legislative branch.election results: percent of vote by party - SBA 73.8%, Ensemble pour Saint-Barthelemy 15.9%, Tous Unis pour Saint-Barthelemy 10.3%; seats by party - SBA 16, Ensemble pour Saint-Barthelemy 2, Tous Unis pour Saint-Barthelemy 1

National anthem.name: "L'Hymne a St. Barthelemy" (Hymn to St. Barthelemy)
National anthem.note: local anthem in use since 1999; as a collectivity of France, "La Marseillaise" is official (see France)

Executive branch.chief of state: President Francois HOLLANDE (since 15 May 2012), represented by Prefect Philippe CHOPIN (since 16 November 2011)
Executive branch.head of government: President of Territorial Council Bruno MAGRAS (since 16 July 2007)
Executive branch.cabinet: Executive Council elected by the Territorial Council; note - there is also an advisory, economic, social, and cultural council
Executive branch.elections/appointments: French president directly elected by absolute majority popular vote in 2 rounds if needed for a 5-year term (eligible for a second term); prefect appointed by the French president on the advice of French Ministry of Interior; president of Territorial Council indirectly elected by its members for a 5-year term; election last held in July 2012 (next to be held in 2017)
Executive branch.election results: Bruno MAGRAS (SBA) reelected president; Territorial Council vote NA

National holiday.value: Fete de la Federation, 14 July (1789); note - local holiday is St. Barthelemy Day, 24 August (1572)

Capital.name: Gustavia
Capital.time difference: UTC-4 (1 hour ahead of Washington, DC, during Standard Time)

Flag description.value: the flag of France is used

Economy - overview.value: The economy of Saint Barthelemy is based upon high-end tourism and duty-free luxury commerce, serving visitors primarily from North America. The luxury hotels and villas host 70,000 visitors each year with another 130,000 arriving by boat. The relative isolation and high cost of living inhibits mass tourism. The construction and public sectors also enjoy significant investment in support of tourism. With limited fresh water resources, all food must be imported, as must all energy resources and most manufactured goods. Employment is strong and attracts labor from Brazil and Portugal.

Telephone system.domestic: direct dial capability with both fixed and wireless systems
Telephone system.international: country code - 590; undersea fiber-optic cable provides voice and data connectivity to Puerto Rico and Guadeloupe (2008)

Broadcast media.value: no local TV broadcasters; 3 FM radio channels (2 via repeater)

Internet country code.value: .bl; note - .gp, the Internet country code for Guadeloupe, and .fr, the Internet country code for France, might also be encountered

Transportation - note.value: nearest airport for international flights is Princess Juliana International Airport (SXM) located on Sint Maarten

Military - note.value: defense is the responsibility of France
